#Text=Melilla
#Text=Melilla ( Arabic : مليلية ( Maliliyyah ) , Berber : ⵎⵔⵉⵜⵙ ( Mřič ) ) is a Spanish exclave in North Africa , on the Moroccan side of the Mediterranean .
#Text=In some ways , it 's kind of like Ceuta but in other ways , it 's a unique place .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Tourist information office , calle Fortuny 21 , ☏ +34 952-67-54-44 .
#Text=Near the Plaza de Toros , but far from everything else .
#Text=A better choice is to go to the Tourist Information kiosk outside the Casino Militar on the main plaza , Plaza Espana .
#Text=Talk
#Text=You are in Spain .
#Text=People speak Spanish .
#Text=But you are also in North Africa , and many people speak Tarifit ( Spanish : rifeño , a variety of Berber ) .
#Text=French is also widely spoken amongst the Moroccans in Melilla .
#Text=By car ( or on foot )
#Text=From Morocco .
#Text=Melilla is completely surrounded by Moroccan territory ( and the sea ) , and this is obviously a very sensitive border .
#Text=Many try to cross illegally into Spain , with dire consequences .
#Text=Crossing legally ( in either direction ) is also an eye-opening experience , but presents no particular difficulties if you are not transporting counterfeit goods or hashish .

#Text=Do n't forget that Spain and Morocco are in different time zones , so crossing the border into Melilla you will lose one hour , or two hours in April and May ( Morocco only started to observe daylight savings time in 2008 ) .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Melilla Airport ( MLN ) .
#Text=The airport was built in the 1960s to replace the old airport that had come under Morocan control in the 1950s .
#Text=Air Nostrum ( Iberia Regional ) flies from Málaga ( 8 flights daily ) , Madrid Barajas ( 3 flights ) , and one flight from Almería , Granada , Valencia and Barcelona El Prat .
#Text=There are no flights to countries other than Spain or to Morocco .
#Text=By boat
#Text=There are ferry services run by Acciona Trasmediterránea and Balearia .
#Text=from Malaga : 8 hours .
#Text=from Almeria : 6.5 hours .
#Text=from Motril : This is a new service from Motril near Granada .
#Text=By train
#Text=Moroccan train operator ONCF has three trains daily between Taourirt and the Beni-Nsar Port train station ( about five minutes ' walk from the border ) .
#Text=Connections are available at Taourirt with trains to Fès , Rabat , Casablanca , and Oujda .
#Text=See
#Text=Melilla la Vieja .
#Text=The fortified old town , on a hill overlooking the port .
#Text=Its ramparts have Roman origins .
#Text=There is an elevator built into the restored city wall .
#Text=Modernismo .
#Text=Architecture , throughout the city , but especially on calle López Moreno and calle del Rey Juan Carlos
#Text=Or Zoruah Synagogue , Calle López Moreno Melilla , 8 .
#Text=Arabesque architecture , designed by Enrique Nieto in 1924 .
#Text=Downstairs a tacky bargain store , but the façade is well-preserved .
#Text=Visits can be arranged through the Tourist Information Kiosk on the Plaza Espana .
#Text=Plaza de España .
#Text=Surrounded by monumental buildings such as the local assembly building , the Casino Militar , and the Bank of Spain .
#Text=Buy
#Text=Melilla ( like Ceuta ) is a territorio franco , which means no VAT or other taxes .
#Text=Eat
#Text=Cafetería Los Arcos , calle López Moreno ( next to the Sagrado Corazón church ) .
#Text=Spanish churros and café con leche , or Moroccan mint tea .
#Text=Cafetería El Galan , calle Remonta ( Straight in front of Melilla Comarcal hospital . ) .
#Text=Andalusian Toast with fresh tomato and olive oil , and typical sandwiches .
#Text=Drink
#Text=The city is full of café/bars but the liveliest part is the Puerto Noray , opposite the big Hotel Puerto Melilla , which has many restaurants , bars and nightclubs .
#Text=And all of the bars look over the marina .
#Text=Sleep
#Text=TRYP Melilla Puerto Hotel , Explanada de San Lorenzo , s/n , ☏ +34912764747 .
#Text=Stay safe
#Text=Melilla is a safe city to visit , though not unconditionally so .
#Text=There are always lots of people enjoying the beach , etc. until late ; though it is not advisable to travel alone at night , even in the city centre .
#Text=Street robbery is not an uncommon occurrence for people walking alone at night in Melilla .
#Text=Pickpocketing is relatively common here , especially in bathrooms where a common tactic is for a group of large men to crowd round the victim and basically empty every available pocket .
#Text=It is a better idea to leave valuables with other friends before going to the bathroom , or failing that , to surreptitiously tuck your phone/wallet etc into your socks .
#Text=Walking into Morocco
#Text=Catch a bus from the Plaza de España to the Moroccan border , 2km to the south .
#Text=Cross the border into the Moroccan customs and security area and line up at the police kiosk to get your passport stamped .
#Text=This can take a while .
#Text=Be sure to go up to the window and ask for an entry form to fill out ( in French , Spanish or English ) while you wait .
#Text=Be careful for scammers trying to sell you these forms or trying to " help " you fill them out .
#Text=They will just run off with your passport .

#Text=When you get out you will be in the village of Beni Enzar which has the port of Nador with sailings to Almeria or France , where you can find banks ( just next to the port)or a collective taxi to the city of Nador .
#Text=Remember to turn your watch back one or two hours !
